Right now, she serves as an active volunteer in her school district and a Family Resource Specialist and trainer for the Parent Training and Information Center and Special Education Volunteer Advocate (SEVA) projects at SPAN NJ Statewide Parent Advocacy Network.
Since then, Tara has taken on a variety of roles working directly with families to provide care and support to children with behavioral disabilities.

The new center is now home to healthcare providers, specialists, and social workers to streamline care for special needs families who often balance multiple care teams.

Now a trusted expert for special needs families, Tara has dedicated her life to serving families like her own, helping parents understand and access the support they need to build better lives for their children.

An "information hound," Tara began taking training courses, becoming an expert in behavioral disabilities, military health care, dispute resolution, childcare, special needs education, & how important it is to spread awareness about behavioral disabilities.  #AutismAwarenessMonth
The more she learned, the better she understood how complicated accessing resources and services were for families with special needs and how those same resources and services could be improved.

I took to the microphones, & I described my understanding of the anger, the distrust, and the feelings of being trapped with nowhere to go. No jobs, no careers, not enough food, and the constant shadow of hostile police, targeting unarmed young black men in particular, for abuse.

My description and discussion of the unrest that took place on April 29th, 1992, described the miserable conditions and police abuse that was so prevalent in Los Angeles and in communities of color in particular.

In the following days, while working on the street, responding to radio calls and telephone interviews, I defined the unrest differently from many outside observers, who claimed the unrest was just a bunch of criminals who wanted to steal and destroy.

I organized to get food, baby diapers, and medicine to the public housing units in South LA, starting with Nickerson Gardens, Jordan Downs, and Imperial Courts housing projects. I then began to work on getting the lights turned on that had been stopped as a result of the unrest.
The next day I made my way to the Public Housing developments in LA because I knew that the poor people there would be isolated and separated from grocery stores and other resources.

Upon arriving in LA on April 29th, the day the insurrection took place, I saw that the streetlights were out, and water was streaming through the streets. The police were everywhere. I got to my home and prepared to deal with the unrest unfolding in the streets.

I immediately reserved a seat on a plane to Los Angeles. During the plane ride, rumors were being spread, that the plane upon entering LA airspace, was going to be targeted with gunshots as a part of the insurrection that was taking place. The rumors did not prove to be true.

Today, I am remembering 30 years ago, I was in Washington D.C. when the news flashed, describing, "LA Riots‚Äù that I referred to as an insurrection, following the nonguilty verdict of the Los Angeles police officers who had viciously beaten Rodney King.
